Award.AbstractNarration:
The theory of dynamical systems studies the long term behavior of deterministic systems. A classical example is the motion of the planets. Dynamical systems arise in all areas of sciences, for instance in physics, biology, and economics. In addition, the methods of dynamical systems can be applied to study problems in other fields of mathematics, including geometry and number theory. There is a well-established theory of chaos that applies to dynamical systems whose nearby trajectories diverge exponentially rapidly with time (the weather is perhaps the most famous example). At the other end of the spectrum, there is regular motion, characterized by slowly-evolving families of trajectories. This research project aims to advance fundamental research on the intermediate case of weakly chaotic systems, often called parabolic. Parabolic systems are characterized by the property that nearby trajectories diverge at most polynomially rapidly with time. Systems of this kind are especially important in geometry, number theory, and mathematical models arising in several branches of physics, including solid-state physics, celestial mechanics, and statistical mechanics. For instance, in recent years, in number theory, and to a lesser extent, in geometry, many questions have been reformulated (sometimes solved) as questions on the dynamics of certain parabolic flows. In physics, the behavior of electrons at the Fermi surface (solid-state physics), the motion of planets near a singularity (celestial mechanics), and the motion of a confined atom (statistical mechanics) are related to parabolic systems. This project aims to develop new approaches to these important questions and will involve graduate students in the fundamental mathematical research.

Dynamical systems can be roughly distinguished according to the speed of divergence of nearby trajectories. Systems with sub-exponential, polynomial divergence of nearby orbits are often called parabolic. An extremely successful approach to some parabolic systems is based on renormalization, which is an effective tool whenever the system reveals itself to be at least approximately self-similar, meaning it is nearly the same when viewed at smaller and smaller scales, possibly after changing of coordinates. However, many fundamental parabolic systems, including most homogeneous flows, do not seem to possess self-similarity properties, and no renormalization method has been developed for such systems. As a consequence, the dynamical properties of these systems are very poorly understood and are rarely the subject of investigation. This project aims to build on recent results by the principal investigator and collaborators to investigate non-renormalizable systems. The guiding principle is to develop a scaling method to generalize renormalization in the absence of self-similarity. Non-renormalizable parabolic systems include higher-step nilflows and higher rank Abelian actions on higher step nilmanifolds. This includes most unipotent Abelian actions on quotients of semisimple Lie groups and billiards in non-rational polygons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI has conducted research on several topics related to the theory of zero entropy parabolic, dynamical systems, which are so far not well understood. Such systems include important examples  coming from physical models, like billiards in polygons, and systems related to questions in number theory and geometry, like unipotent homogeneous flows and their time-changes.   

An important approach to zero entropy systems is via the idea of renormalization, accoding to which the zero entropy dynamics is regarded as a dynamics along the stable manifolds of a hyperbolic system. The power of this approach is considerable, since there is a well-developed theory of hyperbolic systems. The main difficulty in this approach is given by the fact that only a few (parabolic or elliptic) systems with zero entropy are known to be renormalizable.

To advance our understanding of zero entropy dynamics, the PI has worked on certain classes of non-renormalizable systems, such as time-changes of higher step nilflows and billiards in non-rational polygons. As the same time he has worked in several directions to advance the ergodic theory of certain renormalizable systems, in particular translation flows, which are related to billiards in polygons with ''rational'' angles, and time-changes of nilflows on step 2 (Heisenberg) nilflows. 

The PI's research has resulted in 12 research papers and one survey paper, which are already published/ accepted (5) or submitted (7).  The research has been presented regularly at international conferences including recently at online seminars and conferences which have a wider audience. All the papers have posted and are available on the site arXiv.

The main results obtained in the research are the following:

a proof, joint with Jon Chaika,  of the weak mixing property, an important property of mild chaos inergodic theory, intermediate between ergodicity and mixing, for billiards in a dense set of (non-rational) polygons. A result conjectured by Katok and Gutkin in the 80's;

a definitive result on the spectral theory of a class of surface flows, called Koocherging flows, and time-changes of horocycle flows. In a joint paper with Fayad and Kanigowski, the PI has proved that the spectrum is countable Lebesgue. This property had been conjectured by Katok and Thouvenot in 2006 for time changes of horocycle flows;

a result on effective (qualitative) weak mixing for translation flows on higher genus surfaces, based on the introduction of a new twisted cocycle. This work developed and extented to all genera earlier work of Bufetov and Solomyak in genus 2. It develops work of the PI with A. Avila from 2007, where it was proved that the typical translation flow is weakly mixing. In the recent work we prove that the weak mixing happens at polynmial speed with respect to time;

results on decay of correlations of  time-changes of Heisenberg nilflows. These results, joint with A. Kanigowski,  are among the very few available on decay of correlations of non-hyperbolic dynamical systems, and partially confirm the expectation that the decay is polynomial in time;

results on mixing for time-changes of general higher step nilflows. In joint work with Avila, Ravotti and Ulcigrai, the PI has established a dichotomy which esentially states that if a time-change of a nilflow fails to be mixing, it is ony because it is ''trivial'', hence conjugate to the nilflow (which itself is not mixing). 

The PI has mentored sveral younger researchers and has directed two Ph D theses. In particular, he has collaborated with Adam Kanigowski on 3 papers, while he was a post-doc at Penn State University. He has mentored one post-Doc, Changguang Dong, and has directed the PhD thesis of Hamid Al-Saqban and Minsung Kim.   Al-Saqban has completed thesis work on Teichmueller dynamics. Minsung Kim has completed work on equidistribution of higher step nilflows and higher rank (step 2) nilpotent actions.  Both will defined their thesis during Fall 2020 and have already secured  post-docs (Al-Saqban at Boston College, and Kim at University of Torun, Poland) starting in January 2021.
